choices.text: Oral rehydration therapy with a glucose-electrolyte solution
Administration of loperamide for symptomatic relief

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 24-hour history of profuse, watery diarrhea, and mild abdominal cramping. He reports that he recently returned from a trip to Kerala where he consumed local street food. On examination, he appears dehydrated with decreased skin turgor. Stool examination reveals "rice water" stools, and a rapid diagnostic test confirms the presence of Vibrio cholerae. Which of the following treatment strategies is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral rehydration therapy with a glucose-electrolyte solution.

 

Option B:

 

Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) is the cornerstone of treatment for cholera. It replaces the fluids and electrolytes lost through diarrhea and is highly effective at preventing dehydration and death. ORT uses a simple, inexpensive, and readily available glucose-electrolyte solution.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intravenous ciprofloxacin might be used in severe cases, especially if the patient is unable to tolerate oral therapy; however, it is not the initial treatment of choice.

 

Option C. Cholera vaccination is recommended for certain high-risk populations or during outbreaks but is not used for the immediate treatment of an active infection.

 

Option D. Administration of antidiarrheal agents like loperamide is generally avoided in cholera, as they can prolong toxin exposure in the intestines and worsen outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral rehydration therapy is the most appropriate initial treatment for cholera to promptly replace lost fluids and electrolytes.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p336, 2/e p348, Park 22/e p211, 24/e p248

questions.text: A 6-year-old previously healthy boy presents with a 2-week history of severe coughing fits that end with an inspiratory "whoop" and post-tussive vomiting. He attends school and there was a recent outbreak of a similar cough illness in his class. He has received all of his vaccinations according to the CDC schedule. On examination, he is afebrile, and his cough is so severe that it interrupts his breathing and causes his face to turn red. Which antibiotic is the treatment of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythromycin

 

Option D:

 

The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with pertussis, also known as whooping cough, caused by Bordetella pertussis. The preferred treatment for pertussis in children is a macrolide antibiotic. Among the macrolides, eryhromycin is preferred due to its shorter course of treatment and better tolerability. It is also effective in preventing the spread of the disease, which is particularly important in the context of an outbreak.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tetracycline is not the drug of choice for whooping cough and is not recommended for use in children due to its adverse effects on teeth and bones.

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum cephalosporin and is not the first-line treatment for whooping cough.

 

Option C. Azithromycin is an alternative to erythromycin, especially in cases of erythromycin intolerance or in younger children, but erythromycin remains the first choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin as the treatment of choice for pertussis in children, which is effective for both treatment and prophylaxis in the context of an outbreak.

 

Ref: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1024

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant with an incomplete vaccination history is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of episodic coughing followed by an inspiratory "whooping" sound. On examination, the infant appears distressed during coughing spells and turns red, occasionally followed by vomiting. Between episodes, the infant is afebrile and appears well. The cough is severe and the parents are concerned about the child's breathing during these episodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate specimen to collect to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal swab

 

Option C:

 

The most appropriate clinical specimen for the isolation of Bordetella pertussis, the pathogen responsible for whooping cough, is a nasopharyngeal swab. This specimen is collected by swabbing the posterior nasopharynx, which is the site of highest pathogen load. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the preferred diagnostic method and can provide rapid results.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blood culture is incorrect as Bordetella pertussis is not typically isolated from blood.

 

Option B. Throat swab is incorrect because the sensitivity is lower than that of a nasopharyngeal swab for pertussis.

 

Option D. Bronchoalveolar lavage is not typically indicated in the initial diagnostic workup for pertussis in infants due to its invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasopharyngeal swab is the optimal specimen for the detection of Bordetella pertussis in patients suspected of having whooping cough.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p353, 2/e p368, Ananthanarayan9/e p336, 10/e p342, Harrison, 20/e p1144-45, 19/e p1021-23

questions.text: A dairy farmer presents to the clinic with concerns about a potential outbreak of an infectious disease among his cattle. Several cows have exhibited decreased milk production and intermittent fevers. The farmer is aware of the various testing methods used to screen for infectious diseases in livestock and inquires about the test which forms a precipitate at the cream layer of milk samples. Which disease is most commonly associated with this testing method?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brucellosis

 

Option A:

 

The milk ring test is a diagnostic tool used to detect Brucella antibodies in milk, which is indicative of brucellosis in dairy cattle. This test involves the addition of a dye and Brucella antigen to a sample of milk and is based on the principle of antigen-antibody precipitation at the cream layer. This test is valuable in surveillance and control programs for brucellosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis in cattle is usually diagnosed using the tuberculin skin test, not the milk ring test.

 

Option C. Bacteroides is a genus of bacteria that is part of the normal flora of the gut and is not commonly associated with a specific test in dairy cattle.

 

Option D. Salmonellosis diagnosis in cattle does not involve the milk ring test but instead relies on culture and isolation of Salmonella organisms from fecal samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The milk ring test is a diagnostic tool used to detect Brucella antibodies in milk, indicative of brucellosis in dairy cattle. This test involves the addition of a dye and Brucella antigen to milk, based on antigen-antibody precipitation in the cream layer. It is valuable in surveillance and control programs for brucellosis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p360, 2/e p374, Ananthanarayan 9/e p339, 10/e p349

questions.text: A researcher is studying the epidemiology of Brucella melitensis in different livestock populations. They are specifically interested in the transmission dynamics of the pathogen and its primary animal reservoirs. As part of the study, the researcher is compiling data on the incidence of brucellosis in various animals. Which of the following animals is the most common reservoir for Brucella melitensis, which can significantly impact the transmission to humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Goats

 

Option D:

 

Brucella melitensis is primarily associated with small ruminants, particularly goats and sheep. Among these, goats are considered the most significant reservoir for Brucella melitensis, which is a major cause of brucellosis in humans, especially in regions where goat products are consumed or handled.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pigs are more commonly associated with Brucella suis.

 

Option B. Camels can be reservoirs for Brucella but are less commonly implicated than goats for Brucella melitensis.

 

Option C. Sheep are also significant reservoirs for Brucella melitensis but to a lesser extent than goats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goat is the primary animal reservoir for Brucella melitensis and play important role in the zoonotic transmission of brucellosis to humans.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p355, 2/e p374, Ananthanarayan 9/e p339, 10/e p345-346, Harrison, 20/e p1192, 19/e p1066(eChapter 194e)

choices.text: Ingestion of raw vegetables from infected farms
Inhalation of infected dust or aerosol

questions.text: A public health officer is developing educational materials for farm workers to prevent the transmission of zoonotic diseases. Brucellosis is a particular concern, and the materials will include information on the various routes of transmission for this disease. When discussing the transmission of Brucella species to humans, which of the following routes should be highlighted as not being a typical mode of transmission?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Person to person transmission

 

Option C:

 

Brucellosis is primarily transmitted to humans from infected animals or animal products. The most common routes of transmission include direct contact with infected animal tissues (especially the placenta), consumption of unpasteurized dairy products, and inhalation of aerosols. Person to person transmission of brucellosis is extremely rare and not typically included as a major route of transmission in educational or preventive strategies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contact with infected placenta is a well-documented route of Brucella transmission among veterinary workers and those involved in animal husbandry.

 

Option B. Ingestion of raw vegetables contaminated with Brucella from infected farm soil or water can be a potential route of transmission, though less common than others.

 

Option D. Inhalation of infected dust or aerosol is a recognized occupational hazard in meatpacking and other industries involving animal products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Person to person transmission of brucellosis is not a typical mode of transmission and is very rare compared to other routes such as contact with infected animals, consumption of unpasteurized dairy products, and inhalation of aerosols.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p357, 2/e p374, Ananthanarayan 9/e p342, 10/e p346-347, Harrison, 20/e p1194-95

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painful genital ulcer he noticed 3 days ago. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks prior. Which of the following is the most likely incubation period for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chancroid

 

Option D:

 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, typically presents with a painful genital ulcer and may have an incubation period of 2–3 weeks, fitting the clinical scenario described. It is characterized by soft, painful ulcers on the genitals and tender, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Syphilis has a longer incubation period and typically presents with a painless ulcer (chancre).

 

Option B. Herpes genitalis may present sooner than 4–5 weeks and is characterized by painful vesicles or ulcers, not just a singular ulcer.

 

Option C. LGV, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, usually presents with painless ulcers and is followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy after several weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p373, 2/e p388, Ananthanarayan 9/e p372, 421, 331, 420 468, 470, 10/e p379, Harrison, 20/e p1281, 19/e 1134
